channel.title: If you dig a hole
channel.description:
I have two questions to ask.
For both, just imagine that the core didn't exist and you wouldn't burn to death. Its all just soil. If the core did exist in my questions, that would be the answer.
Lets say you are in New York, you dig a hole straight to the other side of the planet. Now out of pure back luck, you dig a whole into a giant ass ocean. Now my question would be, would the hole work like a drain, draining the water into New York? And if so, wouldn't the water drain back? Thats question number one.
Number two, you dig a hole, but end up on land. Now, lets say you jump down the hole feet first, would you end up on the other side with your head first? and if so, when would the blood stop rushing to your head.

item.title: If you dig a hole
item.dc:creator: @dragonfire455 dragonfire455
item.description:
@dragonfire455 wrote:

that may cause some changes to earths gravitational field, idk cos this will never happen, but my theory is that there are two possibilities

1)there will be no gravity and you will float there for all eternity

2)you could keep accelerating and fly out the other end and probaly die from a fall

Read full topic

item.title: If you dig a hole
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

Gravity is the pull between every single object between every two objects, and its strength depends on how close they are and their mass.

You will be pulled to the center of the earth, where in theory you would not be able to go out the other side, because it is “up”.

I actually learned something in science

Read full topic

item.title: If you dig a hole
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“ninja nub, post:44, topic:167996”]First of all, what moron would dig to the center of the earth, you’ll just get stuck at the middle.

Say if you’re digging to the bottom of the earth and you’re in the center, then you’ll be stuck because if you dig in the same direction you were digging, gravity will take over and pull you down. Making you as useless as a vegetable. Since all gravity is pulled towards one specific point in the center of the earth, there will be no hope to digging your way to China.

Second of all, (heres a question) Well, if all gravity is pulled into a point in the center of the earth, what happens if you go there (without a core, obviously)? Will you be crushed? Or will you be sent in confusion because of your balance being WAY off. The world may never know.[/quote]

As you get closer to the center of the earth, gravity becomes weaker.

Read full topic

item.title: If you dig a hole
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

ninja nub:

Say if you’re digging to the bottom of the earth and you’re in the center, then you’ll be stuck because if you dig in the same direction you were digging, gravity will take over and pull you down.

He never said he’d dig it all at once, he could dig half way go to the other side and finish.

ninja nub:

if all gravity is pulled into a point in the center of the earth, what happens if you go there (without a core, obviously)? Will you be crushed?

Force would just be equal, but since two objects cannot occupy the same space at the same time, it is impossible since the core is what would make you gravitate to the center, without the core you wouldn’t be pulled to this void in the center of the earth.

Read full topic

item.title: If you dig a hole
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

JDB`:

Theoretically you would stop wherever the forces are equalized, wouldn’t that be the center?

As you get closer and closer to the center, the force pulling you to the center would decrease to 0. However, you are accelerating this entire time, because the force of gravity was pulling you towards the center. At the center, there is no force acting on you other than friction, so you would continue going at the same fast speed. However, as you pass the center, you start slowing down to a stop. Then you return towards the center. Thus you oscillate until stopped by friction.

Read full topic
